body: Not optimal path extraction from opaque uri.

Merged with commit:
https://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1578984
Hi Christiano - please close this pull request if satisfied (I am unable to close it).
Ok, thanks David...
This change proved to be too disruptive and plain unnecessary. Closing.
Just wondering what's happening here. Is this also a problem in Felix? Do you have a fix? Why was this pull request closed?

No no, no problem.
It's a known bug with equinox (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=350719), and felix may have the same as it does not check the service use count.

So i want to provide a fix, but this was my first use of merge request in github, and i did not created a branch, so all my other modifications has been included in the merge request. This is the reason of the merge request closing.

I will create a branch to merge only this fix, with a dedicated merge request.

Sorry for useless activity ...

Ok great! Just wanted to make sure we won't lose any valuable contributions :)

It might be good to also create a Felix bug at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX to describe the problem, just to have it recorded in the Apache Felix context.

Looking forward to that new merge request!
I have opened a jira for this (4938), but who should close it ? me ?

Thanks for the patch! I have modified it a little bit and applied it in http://svn.apache.org/viewvc?view=revision&revision=1687743

You can close this pull request now (I am not able to do it).
Great, my first patch to felix :)
Congratulations! :)
After a discussion on osgi-dev it was decided that the use case of not holding a string ref to a coordination is invalid. So I am closing this.

As noted on the ticket:
This issue could also be resolved by applying the configuration setting:

`felix.fileinstall.optionalImportRefreshScope=managed`

where fileinstall bundle is not itself managed by fileinstall.
David merged it.

@tyge68 thanks for your patch - it was used as a basis for FELIX-5099 if I'm not mistaken.

Now that FELIX-5099 has been fixed, this issue can also be closed. Please close it if satisfied.

@skahmann it's great that you cleaned up the code, but it makes it very difficult to see what you actually changed. Would you be able to split up your actual fixes and the code-cleanup in separate commits?

Also you could consider using the org.osgi.framework.BundleReference interface instead of the LocalResource interface as its the same. Not sure whether you think this is a good idea, but just a thought...
@bosschaert I created a new PR with restructured commits. Let me know if that's okay: https://github.com/apache/felix/pull/44

@skahmann thanks - your changes look good to me. I ran them through the OSGi Repository CT and those tests are still passing.

Since your change addresses an exception happening in a specific situation, would you be able to provide a unit test for it? This to ensure that this doesn't get broken again?
Associated Felix issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-5112

@bosschaert I added a test to make sure the exception was not thrown. It could be more extensive, but I'm not very familiar with mocking out all the bundle installs and resolution. Let me know if that's okay.

@skahmann thanks for the test, however if I run that test on an unmodified codebase it also passes: I simply took your test commit an applied it to the bundlerepository codebase on trunk and am seeing that it passes, so I guess it's missing something? 

I assume the test should fail if I apply it to the codebase before your code patch...

@bosschaert I was not able to configure the test to run on the previous code because I rely on mocking the LocalResource interface. I did however update my test so that it runs through the deployment code. Perhaps someone more familiar with the implementations can come up with a way to test both versions.
@skahmann thanks - I'll take a look soon.

[Merged in rev 1733098](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FELIX-5203?focusedCommentId=15173979&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15173979) by @cziegeler

In general this looks great, just some questions about that:
1. How does the maven-bundle-plugin behave if m2eclipse-tycho (https://github.com/tesla/m2eclipse-tycho) is installed as well (which can also deal with bundle packagings)?
2. For m2eclipse-tycho the incremental build was explicitly ignored for the manifest generation for performance issue (https://github.com/tesla/m2eclipse-tycho/commit/85cd048ffcd47020992bdec2cd44f1a4945173bf). Since bndlib cannot really deal with incremental updates the manifest generation is quite slow IMHO. Since your addition will require a manifest regeneration whenever any source file was touched I would fear that this really slows down Eclipse. Have you tested your change with bigger bundle projects?

> How does the maven-bundle-plugin behave if m2eclipse-tycho (https://github.com/tesla/m2eclipse-tycho) is installed as well (which can also deal with bundle packagings)?

no idea, never tried. is this in broad use? do you have experience with it?

> Since bndlib cannot really deal with incremental updates the manifest generation is quite slow IMHO

good point - so far i've tested it only with small and mid-sized projects. will do some more testing on big projects.

some ideas to improve this:
- in case of incremental build detect which files changed since last build and trigger manifest generation only if the changeset includes a file with SCR annotations.
- make the incremental build support configurable in the pom - so each project can do the right choice between comfort and performance
- ask the bndlib to add support for incremental SCR generation (no short term solution)

> > How does the maven-bundle-plugin behave if m2eclipse-tycho (https://github.com/tesla/m2eclipse-tycho) is installed as well (which can also deal with bundle packagings)?
> 
> no idea, never tried. is this in broad use? do you have experience with it?

This plugin is automatically offered for installation by m2e through the catalog (https://github.com/takari/m2e-discovery-catalog) whenever some bundle project is imported (see https://github.com/takari/m2e-discovery-catalog/blob/master/org.eclipse.m2e.discovery.oss/src/main/resources-filtered/connectors.xml#L38). Therefore I assume a lot of people have installed it. I assume that with your m2e additions both the m2e connector as well as the bundle-plugins m2e lifecycle management will kick in. But I am not too sure about that either, therefore I asked the question on the m2e-users mailing list (http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/m2e-users/msg05444.html)

>  some ideas to improve this:
> -     in case of incremental build detect which files changed since last build and trigger manifest generation only if the changeset includes a file with SCR annotations.

Actually the manifest will not only change in that case, but also if a new package has been added which does not have "impl" in its name (because it will be automatically exported). Another use case is that the version annotation on the package has been changed (this will be reflected in the export-package directive as well)

> in case of incremental build detect which files changed since last build and trigger manifest generation only if the changeset includes a file with SCR annotations.

You would need to handle the case where a file previously had SCR annotations but it no longer has them -> SCR descriptor needs to be deleted and the MANIFEST updated.
https://github.com/apache/felix/commit/4f659828cdbcdf503b9fde92eb581cd00486fb02
https://github.com/apache/felix/commit/cccd1fd8411736100caa5b7e500636cfc9c0a9e0
Patch applied.

This is a semantics change, as previously the call would cause failures to be re-tried. should failures be empty and files be empty the code would be actually fast.

as I have profiled fileinstall and was responsible for some of the improvements in 3.5.4, i would like to see the profile, maybe i am missing something.
in our case the code is no longer hot and we poll every second hundreds of files.

I'm not sure what you mean. Looking at `Scanner.scan` it news up a `TreeSet` as the return type, the only way i'm getting anything other than a `Set` is an `Exception` which `scan` does not catch, tbh you could probably remove the null check entirely.
https://github.com/set321go/felix/blob/7a6bdb0895674f2359a2a05ee50f802baaa612c2/fileinstall/src/main/java/org/apache/felix/fileinstall/internal/Scanner.java#L131

I can get some of the profiling data next week, I don't have it here.

Hi @dleangen this is an enormous pull request. Are all of these 18 commits really needed for sourceAs(DTO)?

Hi @dleangen these are a lot of different commits. I'm not sure how to review this. Would it be possible to create a separate pull request for each contribution? If a contribution has improved over a number of commits it would be easier to squash all these changes into a single commit so that it's easier to review...

No, things are a bit mixed up. These are changes dating from a few weeks back, and it was very confusing and time consuming to separate them all. Over time, they all got mashed together.

There are basically 3 themes: (1) bugs, (2) changes to make DTO sourcing work, and (3) updates to the Schematizer.

I'll reply to your individual comments and try to work out something easier for you to review.

Hi @dleangen it looks good to me - it's a large pull request so I might have missed something, but I would go ahead and merge.

There is one thing however that we should change, maybe in a separate commit. The serializer contains the org.osgi.service.serialize package for its API and I see that in this commit you added additional interfaces to that API. As at this stage the API is not really coming from OSGi any more and OSGi is currently not actively developing the serialize API, we should rename this package to org.apache.felix.serializer (or something similar) so that people don't get confused about this. Hope you're ok with doing this.

Thank you very much for your comments, @bosschaert. Glad to know that you agree.

I am ok to change the package name. I will create a separate issue, and a separate commit.

I will go ahead and merge this PR.

Thanks again! :-)
@gnodet Kindly review.
At first glance of the README this seems very similar to the OSGi Subsystems specification.  Can you explain the differences?

Hi Tom. I agree that the packaging mechanism looks quite similar (which is intentional) but the runtime handling is different. The resources required by a BAR are installed directly into the OSGi Framework without any kind of isolation between BARs or from the underlying framework. As such it is substantially simpler than the Subsystems spec.

BTW I have been informed that this PR will not be accepted, since I have to follow the process at http://incubator.apache.org/ip-clearance/. However I will leave this PR open for a little while to capture any comments.
